awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Academic Enhancement of Electrical & Computer Engineering Program at Tennessee State University through IoT Research and Integrated Learning Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue science, technology, engineering or mathematics (STEM) graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Tennessee State University will enhance undergraduate education in the Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) department to prepare students to meet the needs of the workforce related to the Internet of Things (IoT) or advanced studies in IoT. Undergraduate students are involved in the project as researchers. 

The key goal of this project is the utilization of cyberlearning or technology tools to supplement and facilitate learning experiences to prepare students with the knowledge and skills required to meet the demand of the industry and the R&D community related to IoT. The project has the objectives to: improve the undergraduate curricula in several courses in the ECE program by integrating IoT theory and concepts; utilize technology tools to facilitate student IoT cyberlearning experiences to supplement curricular knowledge; and provide research experiences to undergraduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
PI: Charles D McCurry

Co-PI: Liang Hong & Leehyun Keel

This project vertically integrated Internet of Things (IoT) concepts, theories, and paradigms into the Electrical & Computer Engineering undergraduate curriculum at Tennessee State University.  The IoT concepts, theories, and paradigms were integrated in freshman to senior level courses in the forms of course lectures, exercises, and class projects.  A subset of undergraduate students participated in funded IoT research during the academic year and summer regarding real-world applications with the senior students applying the acquired IoT knowledge to their capstone design projects.  Undergraduate students were also provided the opportunity to participate in cyberlearning modules regarding IoT to further enhance their knowledge of IoT.  The cyberlearning modules were conducted in the computer, assisted, virtual, environment laboratory (CAVE) at the university which houses a high-resolution 3D stereoscopic projection environment.  During the participation in the cyberlearning modules eye tracking data regarding the student’s attentiveness was collected and an adaptive network-based fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) was developed to predict the attentiveness of the students based on the eye tracking data. These activities stimulated student research interests, enhanced their research skills, and strengthened their preparation for graduate studies.  With Tennessee State University being a Historically Black College/University where many of the students are minorities, the activities of this project contribute to the diversity and hence quality of IoT design and application philosophies and knowledge base in the nation's technology workforce

 


Last Modified: 12/06/2023
Modified by: Charles D Mccurry

por.por_txt_cntn:
PI: Charles D McCurry


Co-PI: Liang Hong & Leehyun Keel


This project vertically integrated Internet of Things (IoT) concepts, theories, and paradigms into the Electrical & Computer Engineering undergraduate curriculum at Tennessee State University. The IoT concepts, theories, and paradigms were integrated in freshman to senior level courses in the forms of course lectures, exercises, and class projects. A subset of undergraduate students participated in funded IoT research during the academic year and summer regarding real-world applications with the senior students applying the acquired IoT knowledge to their capstone design projects. Undergraduate students were also provided the opportunity to participate in cyberlearning modules regarding IoT to further enhance their knowledge of IoT. The cyberlearning modules were conducted in the computer, assisted, virtual, environment laboratory (CAVE) at the university which houses a high-resolution 3D stereoscopic projection environment. During the participation in the cyberlearning modules eye tracking data regarding the students attentiveness was collected and an adaptive network-based fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) was developed to predict the attentiveness of the students based on the eye tracking data. These activities stimulated student research interests, enhanced their research skills, and strengthened their preparation for graduate studies. With Tennessee State University being a Historically Black College/University where many of the students are minorities, the activities of this project contribute to the diversity and hence quality of IoT design and application philosophies and knowledge base in the nation's technology workforce
